response.answer_text: Straight from define:transcendental number - Google Search"In mathematics, a transcendental number is a real or complex number that is not algebraic—that is, it is not a root of a non-zero  polynomial equation with rational coefficients. The most prominent  examples of transcendental numbers are π and e." Lemmie provide gloss on that:The important piece of the definition is a transcendental number is one that could not be readily obtained by any ordinary algebraic process. Examples of some ordinary (not transcendental) numbers:[math]1, 9, \sqrt {2}[/math] I can get "1" by (for example) subtracting four from five:[math5 - 4 = 1[/math]. I can get "9" by (for example) multiplying 3 by itself:[math]3 \cdot 3 = 9[/math] I can get "[math]\sqrt {2}[/math]" by solving: [math]x^2 = 2, x \nless 0[/math]. But what of π?  Although it is defined to be the ratio of a circle's Circumference to its diameter (e.g. [math]\frac {C}{d}[/math]), there is no algebraic process (although there is an iterative formula) that can be used to get the value of π. So too for e.  Although I think getting into a detailed discussion of e's whackiness may not be a good idea right now.-- Furry cows moo and decompress.

A transcendental number is a complex number which is not the root of any polynomial with rational coefficients. For example, [math]\sqrt{2}[/math] is not transcendental because it is a root of the polynomial [math]x^2 - 2[/math] and [math]i[/math] is not transcendental because it is a root of the polynomial [math]x^2 + 1[/math]. It turns out that "most" numbers are transcendental (the set of transcendental numbers is uncountable, and the set of non-transcendental numbers, otherwise known as algebraic numbers, is countable), but it is often difficult to prove that a particular number is transcendental. Some particular transcendental numbers are [math]e, \pi[/math], and [math]2^{\sqrt{2}}[/math]. In many cases we simply don't know whether a number is transcendental, such as the numbers [math]\pi + e, \pi\cdot e[/math], and [math]\gamma[/math] (the Euler-Mascheroni constant). http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transcendental_number
